page.title: 06Farming, south Buriton
page.content: The larger percentage of farmland is owner occupied, with some tennanted acres, is approximately 938 acres and is divided into 2 main soil types, upper greensand & chalk downland. Winter and spring sown barley and wheat are the chief cereals to be grown (522 a) with peas, maize, kale and short term grass leas used as break crops to increase soil fertility and to minimise the propogation of cereal diseases. There are 2 sizeable milking herds and a flock of sheep grazing some 416 acres of grassland, which comprises permanent pasture and short term leas. Grass is also conserved for winter stock feed as silage and engaged in agriculture is much reduced, owing to greater mechanisation. All farmland is interspersed with large afforested areas.3 households keep chicken/ducks.
